paragraphs.content: Chapter 9
paragraphs.contentHtml: Chapter 9

paragraphs.content: Then Job answered and said,
paragraphs.contentHtml: Then Job answered and said,

paragraphs.content: I know it is so of a truth: but how should man be just with God?
paragraphs.contentHtml: I know it is so of a truth: but how should man be just with God?

paragraphs.content: If he will contend with him, he cannot answer him one of a thousand.
paragraphs.contentHtml: If he will contend with him, he cannot answer him one of a thousand.

paragraphs.content: He is wise in heart, and mighty in strength: who hath hardened himself against him, and hath prospered?
paragraphs.contentHtml: He is wise in heart, and mighty in strength: who hath hardened himself against him, and hath prospered?

paragraphs.content: Which removeth the mountains, and they know not: which overturneth them in his anger.
paragraphs.contentHtml: Which removeth the mountains, and they know not: which overturneth them in his anger.

paragraphs.content: Which shaketh the earth out of her place, and the pillars thereof tremble.
paragraphs.contentHtml: Which shaketh the earth out of her place, and the pillars thereof tremble.

paragraphs.content: Which commandeth the sun, and it riseth not; and sealeth up the stars.
paragraphs.contentHtml: Which commandeth the sun, and it riseth not; and sealeth up the stars.

paragraphs.content: Which alone spreadeth out the heavens, and treadeth upon the waves of the sea.
paragraphs.contentHtml: Which alone spreadeth out the heavens, and treadeth upon the waves of the sea.

paragraphs.content: Which maketh Arcturus, Orion, and Pleiades, and the chambers of the south.
paragraphs.contentHtml: Which maketh Arcturus, Orion, and Pleiades, and the chambers of the south.

paragraphs.content: Which doeth great things past finding out; yea, and wonders without number.
paragraphs.contentHtml: Which doeth great things past finding out; yea, and wonders without number.

paragraphs.content: Lo, he goeth by me, and I see him not: he passeth on also, but I perceive him not.
paragraphs.contentHtml: Lo, he goeth by me, and I see him not: he passeth on also, but I perceive him not.

paragraphs.content: Behold, he taketh away, who can hinder him? who will say unto him, What doest thou?
paragraphs.contentHtml: Behold, he taketh away, who can hinder him? who will say unto him, What doest thou?

paragraphs.content: If God will not withdraw his anger, the proud helpers do stoop under him.
paragraphs.contentHtml: If God will not withdraw his anger, the proud helpers do stoop under him.

paragraphs.content: How much less shall I answer him, and choose out my words to reason with him?
paragraphs.contentHtml: How much less shall I answer him, and choose out my words to reason with him?

paragraphs.content: Whom, though I were righteous, yet would I not answer, but I would make supplication to my judge.
paragraphs.contentHtml: Whom, though I were righteous, yet would I not answer, but I would make supplication to my judge.

paragraphs.content: If I had called, and he had answered me; yet would I not believe that he had hearkened unto my voice.
paragraphs.contentHtml: If I had called, and he had answered me; yet would I not believe that he had hearkened unto my voice.

paragraphs.content: For he breaketh me with a tempest, and multiplieth my wounds without cause.
paragraphs.contentHtml: For he breaketh me with a tempest, and multiplieth my wounds without cause.

paragraphs.content: He will not suffer me to take my breath, but filleth me with bitterness.
paragraphs.contentHtml: He will not suffer me to take my breath, but filleth me with bitterness.

paragraphs.content: If I speak of strength, lo, he is strong: and if of judgment, who shall set me a time to plead?
paragraphs.contentHtml: If I speak of strength, lo, he is strong: and if of judgment, who shall set me a time to plead?

paragraphs.content: If I justify myself, mine own mouth shall condemn me: if I say, I am perfect, it shall also prove me perverse.
paragraphs.contentHtml: If I justify myself, mine own mouth shall condemn me: if I say, I am perfect, it shall also prove me perverse.

paragraphs.content: Though I were perfect, yet would I not know my soul: I would despise my life.
paragraphs.contentHtml: Though I were perfect, yet would I not know my soul: I would despise my life.

paragraphs.content: This is one thing, therefore I said it, He destroyeth the perfect and the wicked.
paragraphs.contentHtml: This is one thing, therefore I said it, He destroyeth the perfect and the wicked.

paragraphs.content: If the scourge slay suddenly, he will laugh at the trial of the innocent.
paragraphs.contentHtml: If the scourge slay suddenly, he will laugh at the trial of the innocent.

paragraphs.content: The earth is given into the hand of the wicked: he covereth the faces of the judges thereof; if not, where, and who is he?
paragraphs.contentHtml: The earth is given into the hand of the wicked: he covereth the faces of the judges thereof; if not, where, and who is he?

paragraphs.content: Now my days are swifter than a post: they flee away, they see no good.
paragraphs.contentHtml: Now my days are swifter than a post: they flee away, they see no good.

paragraphs.content: They are passed away as the swift ships: as the eagle that hasteth to the prey.
paragraphs.contentHtml: They are passed away as the swift ships: as the eagle that hasteth to the prey.

paragraphs.content: If I say, I will forget my complaint, I will leave off my heaviness, and comfort myself:
paragraphs.contentHtml: If I say, I will forget my complaint, I will leave off my heaviness, and comfort myself:

paragraphs.content: I am afraid of all my sorrows, I know that thou wilt not hold me innocent.
paragraphs.contentHtml: I am afraid of all my sorrows, I know that thou wilt not hold me innocent.

paragraphs.content: If I be wicked, why then labour I in vain?
paragraphs.contentHtml: If I be wicked, why then labour I in vain?

paragraphs.content: If I wash myself with snow water, and make my hands never so clean;
paragraphs.contentHtml: If I wash myself with snow water, and make my hands never so clean;

paragraphs.content: Yet shalt thou plunge me in the ditch, and mine own clothes shall abhor me.
paragraphs.contentHtml: Yet shalt thou plunge me in the ditch, and mine own clothes shall abhor me.

paragraphs.content: For he is not a man, as I am, that I should answer him, and we should come together in judgment.
paragraphs.contentHtml: For he is not a man, as I am, that I should answer him, and we should come together in judgment.

paragraphs.content: Neither is there any daysman betwixt us, that might lay his hand upon us both.
paragraphs.contentHtml: Neither is there any daysman betwixt us, that might lay his hand upon us both.

paragraphs.content: Let him take his rod away from me, and let not his fear terrify me:
paragraphs.contentHtml: Let him take his rod away from me, and let not his fear terrify me:

paragraphs.content: Then would I speak, and not fear him; but it is not so with me.
paragraphs.contentHtml: Then would I speak, and not fear him; but it is not so with me.
